value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">34</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">much sharper. As these faculties became atrophied,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he became more conscious of the suggestions and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">associations of words. Txxxs One word written in 
            <choice>
              <sic>Elizabathn</sic>
              <corr>Elizabethan</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">spelling bxmxmxmxmx xxxx has suggestions that give it</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">almost another meaning. It suggests other manners, other</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">clothes; the difference between one society and another.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Then as reading becomes a universal habit, readers split</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">off into many varieties. There are the specialised readers,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">whose power of 
            <choice>
              <sic>darwing</sic>
              <corr>drawing</corr>
            </choice> out the meaning of words is</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">tremendously developed; so that they remain attached to 
            <choice>
              <sic>certn</sic>
              <corr>certain</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">aspects of the printed wxxdxx page--the scholars, the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">students. At the opposite end of the scale, there is the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">very large class of perfectly literate people whose eyes</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">travel over miles of print yearly, yet never read a word.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><add hand="ms" place="above">Some <del hand="ms">way</del> <add hand="ms" place="above">where</add> between the two,</add> The reader at the present moment exxxxxsx is placed somewhere</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">between these two extremes. And his faculty is a very</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>curous</sic>
              <corr>curious</corr>
            </choice> one. He has the power to make houses and</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">places, men and women and their thoughts and emotions</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>isible</sic>
              <corr>visible</corr>
            </choice> to him, from marks on a piece of paper.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Somehwere</sic>
              <corr>Somewhere</corr>
            </choice> between the two comes the reader. His faculty is a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">very curious one. He has the power to make houses and places</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">visible from marks on a 
            <choice>
              <sic>ipiece</sic>
              <corr>piece</corr>
            </choice> of paper; to draw 
            <choice>
              <sic>emitons</sic>
              <corr>emotions</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of 
            <choice>
              <sic>very</sic>
              <corr>every</corr>
            </choice> kind; and also some quality that is independent</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of emotion; form; unity. He is capable of all the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">impulses of a writer; but lacks the power of creation.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">His 
            <choice>
              <sic>influnece</sic>
              <corr>influence</corr>
            </choice> upon what is 
            <choice>
              <sic>wr tten</sic>
              <corr>written</corr>
            </choice> at any time is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">immense; In times of public stress, for instance, the writer</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">is 
            <choice>
              <sic>uincapable</sic>
              <corr>incapable</corr>
            </choice> of 
            <choice>
              <sic>swriting</sic>
              <corr>writing</corr>
            </choice>; in part at least because</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he has no audience. The life of a reader is thus</l>
